transcripts.text: Good day, everyone.  A warm welcome to the debate on Press TV.  I'm your host, Behrouz Najafi.  It seems that humanitarian aid has emerged to serve as a key political battleground in the Venezuelan crisis.  President Nicolas Maduro has blocked aid, accusing the U.S.  of using the issue to stir trouble in his country.  He has shot the Brazil border and saying that he may do the same to the Colombia border, if need be.  Now, in Define, self-proclaimed President Juan Guaido insists that he will personally collect food and medicine gathered at the border on Saturday.  Maduro and Russia regard the U.S.  aid as a move aimed at toppling the Caracas government.  What's the U.S.  seeking by pushing for the aid?  Is it really concerned about a dire economic situation in Venezuela?

A tense standoff between Venezuela's U.S.-backed opposition leader Juan Guaido and President Nicolas Maduro over allowing in humanitarian aid has drawn reactions from other world countries.  Russia has accused the U.S.  of using aid deliveries as a ploy to carry out military action against the Maduro government.

It can cause clashes between the supporters and the opponents of the current regime and serve as a convenient pretext for conducting military action to topple the current legitimate president of the country.
China has also produced a similar reaction.

If the so-called humanitarian assistance were forcefully sent to Venezuela, it might trigger conflict and lead to serious consequences.  This is not what anyone wants to see.  China is against a military intervention in Venezuela and against any behavior that might cause escalation or even turmoil in Venezuela.

President Maduro has ordered the closure of Venezuela's land border with Brazil and threatened to close the frontier with Colombia to prevent the American supplied assistance from entering the country.  The Venezuelan president says he is happy to accept aid shipments overseen by the UN, but he has slammed the aid Guaido seeks to bring in as a precursor to a U.S.  military intervention in the oil-rich country and also a strategy to overthrow his government.  Guaido, who sparked a deep crisis last month by declaring himself the interim leader, has vowed to move aid from the US and other nations inside Venezuela in defiance of the Maduro government.  Maduro has accused the opposition of seeking to stage a coup with the support of the US, which he said is seeking to govern Venezuela from Washington.  The accusation by Maduro is reminiscent of the 2002 coup against late Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, which only lasted 48 hours.  At that time then US President George W. Bush endorsed the coup leader.  President Donald Trump also recognized Guaido as the Latin American nation's interim president and didn't exclude the possibility of using military force against Maduro.
All options are on the table.

The US's long history of intervening in Latin American nations has raised fears that the ongoing political tensions in Venezuela could snowball into uncontrolled violence and ultimately force Venezuelans to bear the brunt of US intervention.

President Nicolas Maduro has rejected the US aid offer.  He is saying that this is part of a broader attempt to overthrow his government.  Russia is also saying that aid is a pretext for military action.

The Washington Post is reporting that two people have been killed.  The blood is on President Trump's hands.  It's on the so-called interim president, Guaido, who has been a willing puppet to put this confrontation into place.
What do you think the so-called humanitarian aid from Washington is really aimed at?

The aid, yes, the U.S.  is trying to stir up there.  They do not want to become yet another battlefield for U.S.  war of liberation as Iraq and Syria suffered.  It's a very perilous thing, almost the worst thing in the world.  For me to be liberated by the United States guarantees you 20 years of foreign devastation afterwards if you look at the Middle Eastern examples.
Right.  Cheryl?

President Maduro received 6.2 million votes in the May 20th election.  This is not a question of illegitimacy.  This is a question of the United States trying to gain domination over the oil like it had before President Chavez.  We cannot stand for the United States trying to take over the resources and sow destruction and war in its path all around the globe.  It's done it in North Africa, it's done it in the Middle East, and now it's attempting to do it in Latin America as well, and we have to say no.

The United Nations, the Red Cross, and other relief organizations, they have refused to work with the U.S.  in terms of delivering the aid to Venezuela.  Well, they argue that a U.S.  aid is politically motivated.

The U.S.  is playing a bad role, as it almost invariably does, but particularly in light of Trump, of course.  I think if you were dying on the street and Trump came to you with an oxygen mask, you'd have at least several thoughts about it.

If you look at what the U.S.  policy has done throughout Central America, throughout Latin America, and throughout the world, it has created a huge refugee crisis that dwarfs anything that anyone can point to in terms of Venezuela.  This is... Something that the United States has instigated.  They tried to get all of the opposition parties not to participate in the elections and in fact the ones who did were vilified.  Guaido didn't even run in the election.  Who is he?  He was trained in Washington.  He was trained in Washington.  We have to look at this historically and in a global sense.  The United States has to stop the sanctions, stop the war, has to get out of Venezuela and Latin America and quit meddling in everybody else's internal affairs.  The question is not Maduro.  The question is not Venezuela.  The question is the United States and what it's doing.  $5.9 trillion has been spent by the U.S.  military just on the books, not including all the secret funds, since 9-11, 2001.  So there's a huge amount of resources that are being put into the U.S.  military, and they are going to use it.  Why is Elliott Abrams going there on a military... Why is he going there at all?  but he's going there on a military helicopter to oversee this confrontation.  This has nothing to do with the poor and working people of Venezuela who have gotten 2.5 million houses, whose children are going to school, who are receiving food and medicine and are willing to accept assistance from around the world, but are not willing to accept it on U.S.  tanks and military helicopters.

That's right.  They also said they will accept it from Russia that's ready for that.  If the U.S.  is really concerned about the humanitarian situation of Venezuela, it can simply remove those sanctions.  There was this special rapporteur, a special envoy to Venezuela, whose report was never reported.  And we talked to him, and he said that sanctions are hurting Venezuelans.  A book by former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe reveals that Trump privately discussed going to war with Venezuela in 2017 because, quote, they have all the oil and that they are in the U.S.  back door.

The president's remarks to the room were along the lines of, I don't understand why we're not looking at Venezuela.  Why are we not at war with Venezuela?  They have all the oil and they're right on our back door.  These were comments that caused us deep concern.
Are we looking for a repeat of the Iraq scenario?

Well, I think we're starting to see it.  I want to remind the viewers that in 2002, when there was a coup against President Chavez, there was a lie that was told that the Bolivarian Chavistas were the ones who were shooting on demonstrators.  It was shown by an Irish TV team that was there and later made a movie called The Revolution Will Not Be Televised.  that these reports by Western media, by the corporate media were totally false and they were used as an excuse for the United States to support that coup.  We have to be very vigilant that people do not get trapped into supporting a false war by some tragic occurrence in Venezuela that winds up being an excuse.
We only have less than one minute time left.  One last question for both of you.  Each one of you have 30 seconds only.  Cheryl, how likely is a U.S.  military intervention in Venezuela?

It feels like it's very likely.  And the argument that's being presented by the other respondent here is an argument to disarm the people around the world who are saying no war on Venezuela, U.S.  out, no sanctions.
Okay, Ian Williams.

No US war on Venezuela.  Most Venezuelans agree with that as well.  And I think it's highly unlikely.  Trump might try it, but he doesn't have a coalition that's prepared to support this anywhere else in the world.  He doesn't have the forces at home.  The American people, jaded though they are, are sick of the wars that they've already been embroiled in and the consequences.  I really can't see this happening.  Almost Trump would have to stage a military coup in Washington to be able to wage a war in Venezuela.  And I hope that there's too much sanity, even in the Pentagon, to countenance that at the moment.

Okay, unfortunately, we're out of time.  Let me thank our guests.  We have writer and anti-imperialist activist Sheryl LaPage from Washington,  D.C.,  and senior analyst with Foreign Policy and Focus, Ian Williams from New York.  And thank you for watching the debate.  We'll see you soon.

Please use the YouTube tools to share this video.  Share the link to this video with everyone you can to get the word out.  Hands off Venezuela.  And please subscribe and click the bell.  Even subscribing and clicking the bell helps.  And also check out this video, the full version of this video from the Bolivian president where he goes into detail about the wrongs of U.S.  foreign policy.  There's an annotation to this video around the end of this video or in the video description.  Thank you.
